 ECUADOR MODERNIZATION OF THE STATE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROJECT TECHNICAL ANNEX SECTION A: PROJECT DESCRIPTION Background 1. The centralized and control-oriented public management framework that exists in Ecuador today provides neither the managerial capacity nor the managerial incentives required for effective and efficient management. That this is the case in Ecuador today is apparent from the widespread lack of confidence in and disillusionment with the public sector's capacity to deliver basic public services. This centralized and control-oriented public management framework makes it extremely difficult to effectively and efficiently manage those public resources to achieve the fundamental aims of the Government because effective management requires both the capacity to tailor managerial decisions to the constantly changing conditions faced by any given executing unit (i.e., competent managers endowed with adequate autonomy to materially affect the performance of their units) and an appropriately designed incentive framework that ensures that managers will use such discretion and autonomy to serve the ends of the Government, rather than the narrower aims of either their particular organizational unit or themselves personally. 2. This pattern is not unique to Ecuador. It can be found throughout most of Latin America. Furthermore, the creation of such a centralized and control-oriented public management framework represents a not entirely irrational response to a very real problem; namely, the risk of misuse or abuse of authority by public servants who are not always models of moral uprightness or technical or managerial competence. Unfortunately, such a response to this risk of the misuse of public resources brings with it a number of debilitating drawbacks. Perhaps the two most important of these drawbacks are: (i) such a framework makes it extremely difficult to effectively and efficiently manage within the public sector; while (ii) this very difficulty induces public agencies, their managers and even politicians to seek out all manner of ad hoc devices for circumventing the bottlenecks to effective management created by this centralized and control-oriented management framework, thereby both reducing the transparency of the overall system while simultaneously undermining its capacity to prevent the mismanagement and abuse of authority it was designed to preclude in the first place. 3. That this centralized and control-oriented public management framework has led to the proliferation of all manner of devices for circumventing and subverting those centrally imposed controls is reflected in numerous symptoms of a public sector gone awry, including: a consistent pattern of public employment growth; a proliferation of organizational units created outside the normal budgetary and personnel control apparatus; a proliferation of off- budget items and earmarked revenues; a proliferation of labor regimes within the public
 2 Technical Annex sector and a weakened public sector human resource management capacity; a proliferation of salary supplements; inability of the Government to recruit and retain middle level management, professional and technical personnel. 4. Public employment growth. Public employment in Ecuador has grown inexorably over the last decade and one-half, regardless of whether it is measured in absolute terms or relative to population (see Table 1 and Figure 1). The only significant reversal of this trend occurred in 1993, when the Government took initial steps toward its Modernization of the State program (see below). Total public employment exclusive of uniformed military personnel climbed from 193,000 in 1979 to almost 370,000 in 1992, and finally dipped to just under 342,000 in 1993. As a share of population, public employment rose from roughly 2.5% at the beginning of the 1980s to 3.35% by 1992, and finally dipped to 3.02% in 1993. Were the Government to set itself the goal of reducing public employment to its early-1980s levels relative to population, it would need to eliminate another roughly 50,000 positions by the end of 1995, assuming population growth continues at its recent rate of roughly 2.4% per annum. 5. This inexorable growth in public employment could hardly be attributed to a smoothly functioning centralized control-oriented framework aimed at keeping public employment in check. It represents, instead, evidence that despite the numerous aspects of that framework aimed at controlling things such as public employment growth, the final result is just the reverse. The turnaround in 1993 raises the question whether the Government has finally figured out how to stem the tide of employment growth or whether this downtick is simply an aberration. 6. Proliferation of public agencies partially or wholly exempt from core financial and personnel management controls. As of 1992 the Offices of the Presidency and the Vice Presidency plus the 14 Ministries counted 46 ascribed entities, 11 autonomous institutions, 20 autonomous enterprises and 5 decentralized entities under their purview. Each of these 82 entities represents an exemption from the core control-oriented framework operative within the public sector. This plethora of exempt or partially exempt entities has resulted from attempts over the years to create more flexible, independent public entities capable of managing resources more effectively than is feasible within the core control-oriented framework. This proliferation, then, represents a clear indictment of that framework. If that framework did not represent a significant impediment to effective management, the incentive to create such exempt or semi-exempt entities would be considerably weaker; and only a fraction of these 82 entities would probably exist. Significantly, when the Government enacted the Modernization of the State Law at the end of 1993, and its subsequent regulation, which aimed at correcting many of the flaws in the existing public management framework, it created just such an exempt autonomous entity to shepherd that modernization process -- the National Council for Modernization of the State (CONAM); yet another piece of evidence that the existing central control-oriented framework is widely recognized as part of the problem rather than part of the solution to improving the performance of the public sector in Ecuador.
 3 Technical Annex 7. Proliferation of off-budget items and earmarked revenues. The Government's budget formulation, execution and monitoring process is plagued with a proliferation of off-budget items and earmarked revenues. These devices for circumventing the centralized and control- driven budget process have proliferated specifically to avoid those centralized controls. They represent yet another indictment of the ineffectiveness of that centralized framework: firstly, it undermines managerial capacity, thereby engendering efforts to circumvent its constraints; and secondly, each successful circumvention of those controls further erodes the capacity of that system to either control expenditures or hold public managers accountable for the resources they employ and the results they obtain with those resources. 8. The most obvious and glaring absence of full accounting in the budget is for the resources allocated to the National Defense. Although the budgetary allocation to the Ministry of Defense covers all projected direct compensation and a few additional expenditures, it lacks the bulk of the purchases of materiel, since those are undertaken with off-budget earmarked funds primarily from petroleum revenues. The military also controls several public companies such as FLOPEC and TRANSNAVE, and is able to administer funds arising from these companies with some leeway. With regard to the allocations to the different ministries, the current budget system only allocates the direct costs of the programs actually administered by the ministries along with the budgetary transfers to the numerous entities ascribed to the ministries: entities that actually operate programs within the purview of the ministries. Similarly, the allocations for external debt servicing only includes those institutions that are fully incorporated into the budget and any explicit budgetary allocations for the debt servicing of those entities not included in the budget. 9. The proposed budget also fails to fully reflect salary costs. By law, the budget is presented to Congress in the last week of September of the previous year, and only includes the known scheduled increases in public salaries. Since most of the negotiations for salaries take place at the beginning of the fiscal year, the proposed budget usually severely underestimates the final expenditures for wages and salaries. Not only does the budget provide only a limited picture of public sector expenditure, but public and official debate is quite limited. The budget evaluation also lacks the systematic input of affected groups. 10. The existence of numerous and significant expenditures that are not reflected in the budget and accounting records of the Government is, like the proliferation of exempt and semi-exempt entities, a reflection of continuous organizational and political end-runs around the centralized control-oriented management framework in order to protect particular programs or units and to permit them greater autonomy over their allocation of those

In short, the weak expenditure setting and execution capacities of the Government reflect the continual and inexorable forces seeking means of circumventing the managerially debilitating impacts of the centralized control-oriented financial management framework. The passage of the Budget Law of 1992 is only the most recent reflection of the same widespread disaffection with the incomplete and ineffective expenditure setting and execution capacity that has resulted from these continual, and often successful, attempts to evade the constraints of the centralized control-oriented financial management framework. 11. Proliferation of public sector labor regimes and weakened human resource management capacity. Only about 16% of the total public sector labor force is actually subject to the Ley de Servicio Civil y Carrera Administrativa. The remainder is subject to various sector-specific public sector labor regimes (68%) (e.g., teachers, national police, customs administration personnel, universities and poly-technical schools, or other public agency labor regimes); is governed by any of a large number of collective contracts (15%); or are hired under individual personal services contracts or are outside the normal labor regimes (1 %) (see Table 2). This proliferation of labor regimes is another manifestation of the failure of the centralized input-control-oriented management framework. The extreme rigidity of the framework established by the Ley de Servicio Civil y Carrera Administrativa and its centralized administration, the uncompetitive salaries allowed under that regime, the bureaucratic red tape engendered by that regime in various types of personnel actions (e.g., in hiring, transferring, promoting and dismissing employees; in adjusting annual salaries, etc.) have led not only individual public managers, but the legislature itself to design a plethora of parallel labor regimes ostensibly better tailored to the unique circumstances of specific sectors (e.g., education, police, armed forces, etc.). It also contributed to the incorporation of Article 125 in the Constitution of 1975, which allowed public sector workers to form unions and negotiate collective contracts with their employers. Public employees have taken advantage of this latter provision to do just that; i.e., they have used yet one more device for circumventing a dysfunctional, centralized, input-control-oriented human resource management regime. 12. In short, the proliferation of public sector labor regimes, including the increasing incidence of public employees governed by collective contracts under the private sector labor law, constitute yet one more indictment of a malfunctioning management framework. This proliferation not only illustrates widespread disillusionment with that centralized management framework. At the same time, this proliferation undermines the Government's capacity to meet even the basic aim of its centralized, input-control-oriented civil service framework -- namely, preventing misuse and abuse of authority over publicly managed resources -- since each of the multitude of labor regimes exempt from the basic civil service framework tend to be created with an eye to protecting the interests of the parties most directly affected by those exempt labor regimes -- be it teachers, police, members of the individual public sector labor unions, etc.
 7 Technical Annex 13. Difficulty in recruiting and retaining middle level management, professional and technical personnel. Centrally fixed public sector salaries are low relative to those available in the domestic private sector. More importantly, this discrepancy is more pronounced among positions requiring higher level skills, such as managerial and higher level professional positions. Table 3 reveals that within a sample of Central Government offices and Ministries that encompasses many of the core Central Government functions, Directors and Directors General receive on average only between about 6% and 29% of the compensation their private sector counterparts receive; professionals receive between about 25% and 55% of their private sector counterparts; technical personnel receive between about 40% and 63% of the remuneration available for comparable positions in the private sector; while low-skilled service workers tend to receive between about 50% and 100% of their private sector counterparts. These comparisons are based on averages within career tracks in each of these public agencies relative to specific private sector position types. As such, they do not provide as clean a comparison as one would like. Nevertheless, their general pattern is unmistakable: the higher the skill level, the less well remunerated are Central Government employees relative to their private sector counterparts. 14. Under these conditions, it is not surprising to find that the Central Government has considerable difficulty attracting and retaining highly skilled employees. Nor is it surprising to find the previously mentioned widespread practices of hiring many high skill employees under contractual arrangements that circumvent the civil service salary structure. While such maneuvers solve the immediate problem faced by the executing unit, they ultimately undermine the capacity of those units to function effectively; both because such practices often undermine morale of the career civil servants and because excessive reliance on such spot market contractual arrangements for key managerial functions can undermine the institutional memory and shared institutional priorities and behavioral norms required for effective management. 15. Proliferation of salary supplements. This pattern of not only lower wages in the public sector, but progressively lower remuneration as the skill requirements increase is no secret among higher level officials. Besides being widely recognized as a major contributor to the difficulty of recruiting and retaining highly skilled managers and professionals, it has also generated a plethora of salary supplements -- each aimed at some particular class of public employees -- intended to counter the uncompetitive public sector salaries permitted under the general salary scale. Whether that proliferation actually succeeds in bringing the pattern of public sector salaries more into line with the private sector competition is difficult to ascertain, since the budget data upon which the comparisons in Table 3 are based unreliably measure total remuneration due to the budgeting of an unspecified component of salary supplements in the "transfers" budget category.

Over the years, base salaries have been augmented by adding 13th, 14th, 15th and 16th month salaries to each civil servant's base salary, in an ad hoc attempt to top up public sector salaries that were inexorably falling behind their private sector counterparts. But this device has proved less than fully capable of keeping public sector salaries at any reasonable fraction of private sector comparators. As a consequence, a plenitude of additional salary supplements have come into existence, not only for career civil servants but also for public workers governed by other labor regimes, such as collective contracts. No fewer than 32 such supplements currently exist in one or more of these labor regimes (see ?). 17. These salary supplements pose at least two serious problems. First, some of them intended to reflect job demands -- such as level of responsibility, experience requirements, education requirements, training requirements, etc. -- create perverse incentives. Salary supplements for training received, for instance, create strong incentives for public employees to seek training in order to qualify for the salary supplement, regardless of whether that training improves their on-thejob performance. Since the budgetary system automatically increases a budget executing unit's budget to cover these training-linked salary supplements, line managers have no incentive to discourage their employees from obtaining useless training. Furthermore, those managers are likely to view this device as a means of enhancing their employees' salaries at no cost to their unit. 18. Second, many of these salary supplements are tied to factors that have nothing to do with job demands and represent little more than a string of ad hoc attempts to enhance salaries of particular, easily mobilized subsets of employees without overhauling the basic salary structure by providing targeted salary supplements based on various personal or family circumstances (e.g., birth of a child, death, housing assistance, domestic calamity, housing calamity, family allowance, etc.). 19. In sum, the highly centralized, input-control oriented public management system that has evolved in Ecuador fails in its primary aim; to control and limit the use of publicly held financial and human resources. Public employment, for instance, grew inexorably over the last decade and one-half. More importantly, it actually generates the seeds of its own malfunctioning. The highly centralized budget system has generated a proliferation of devices for circumventing the normal budgetary process, including earmarked revenues and off-budget activities. Similarly, the centralized financial control system, including but not limited to both the extremely cumbersome procurement process and the reliance on pre- control, have led to the proliferation of autonomous entities exempt from many of those controls. The highly centralized personnel management system has also generated a plethora of labor regimes, salary supplements and other devices for circumventing the controls built into that system. 20. Even more importantly, however, that system undermines good management and generates poor management of public resources. For all of these reasons, the Government of Ecuador is now undertaking to create a public management framework that will ensure fiscal control without undermining public management capacity; a framework that will reward

Management Reform Efforts The Public Budgets Law mandated program budgeting, which is an important step forward. Highlights of this Law include: (a) increased coverage of the obligation to submit budget proformas to the MFCP, to include the entire central administration; (b) introduction of program budgeting; (c) reduction of earmarking, introduction of requirements for justification of earmarked funds; (d) utilization of the banking system for public sector payments; (e) requirement for public sector cash management, with annual cash programs initially prepared by executing agencies and authorized by SP and ST; (f) replacement of individual expenditure authorization by SP and ST with monthly credit line replenishments based on the pre-approved cash programs; (g) requirement for investment planning, giving SGP responsibility for investment project approval; (h) provision for multi-year investment programs. 22. But despite its intellectual appeal, program budgeting has a sorry implementation history. The typical pattern is for agencies to develop both a line item budget and a performance budget -- the latter to satisfy reporting requirements, while the former really guides both management decision-making and the legislature's budget allocation process. For program budgets to alter resource allocation decisions, the incentive structure facing management must also change in a way that makes both management and the political authorities condition their resource allocation decisions on program outcomes, rather than on programs as budget aggregations (i.e., organizational units or bureaucracies). In the latter case, budgetary decisions typically take the form of adding a modest increment to each program's (organizational unit's) previous budget period's allocation; while managers of programs operate under the same input-control oriented public management framework as they did under a line-item budgetary process. The result is no behavioral change other than the generation of a second budget presentation. Consequently, for the program budget mandated by the Ley de Presupuesto to yield any tangible improvements, it must be accompanied by changes in the incentive structure faced by public managers and political decision-makers.

Fortunately, the Modernization of the State Law (LMOS) provides a mechanism for accomplishing this; namely, the public agency restructuring process mandated in that law.
 14 Technical Annex For that restructuring process to materially affect the service delivery performance of particular public agencies, it must build incentives around the outputs of the programs for which the Budget Law mandates budget formulation, execution, reporting and control. This cannot be accomplished by central fiat. It requires that incentives be built into the management framework faced by public agencies and their managers, and that those incentives be fundamental enough and large enough to elicit management's commitment to effectively and efficiently produce the outputs for which their agencies are responsible. The Modernization of the State Technical Assistance Project is designed specifically to address this challenge. It builds on the framework established by the Government in these two milestone laws -- the Public Budgets Law and the Modernization of the State Law. 24. Besides securing the approval of important legislation, since assuming office in August 1992, the Government has taken a number of administrative measures to modernize its economy and reform its public sector. The public sector payroll has been reduced by 21,000 employees representing more than 5 percent of public employment, and the Government has begun to contract with the private sector for the delivery of important services. The Government has also begun a program of public sector divestiture and deregulation of the economy, with the sale of public sector assets and shares owned in small enterprises and with the elimination of a large number of obsolete regulations. The Government has advanced the development of procedures for implementation of the Budget Law, and has developed a strategy to establish an incentive program for the restructuring of public sector agencies, whereby those agencies that meet certain goals of employment reduction and sales of assets can apply a portion of the savings to improve the existing depressed salary scale. At least five public entities, or units thereof, have already been restructured according to preliminary guidelines developed by SENDA. 25. Future Priorities. The reforms in the public sector aim to restructure ministries and agencies according to a process of redefinition of objectives and goals and to modernize their management. A key tool for effecting those changes and establishing better priorities in public sector will be the implementation of the Budget Law. 26. This will entail the need for all public sector institutions to present their budget for review and certification by the Ministry of Finance, before approval. The presentation of the Budget will have to be accompanied by a catalog of their activities, programs, objectives, measurable goals, the number of civil servants and positions available, and their debts. During the presentation of the 1996 Budget, the Government will introduce the multi-annual budgeting plan as called for under the law. 27. The law also requires, and the Executive will ensure, that all investment projects by public sector entities be included in the annual investment plans and reviewed by the Secretariat of Planning (SGP) before its inclusion in the budget. For this purpose, SGP will have to strengthen its capacity to analyze investment projects and to issue rulings on the project's compliance with sound investment criteria. The Government is preparing an
 15 Technical Annex implementation plan outlining the criteria for such reviews and the measures that will be taken to guarantee the capacity of SGP to attend to its mandate. 28. An important change in budgetary execution will be the elimination before January 1995 of existing drawing authorizations (cupos de giros) for each expenditure by MFCP. A new system of authorizations will be extended according to cash flow programming that is consistent with each agency's budget. The transfer of funds will be done automatically with the introduction of a budget payments system through the private banking network. This new form of payments will replace the existing central control with a decentralized system of budgetary management, thereby greatly increasing efficiency and establishing accountability. The Executive is coordinating closely with the Central Bank of Ecuador (BCE) in the introduction of the new payments system to ensure it contributes to the appropriate management of monetary and macroeconomic policies. 29. The Budget Law made a substantial contribution to sound fiscal management by limiting the practice of earmarking of revenues. To ensure that future legislation does not weaken or erode the progress achieved so far, the Executive is committed to prevent the introduction of any earmarking provisions not consistent with its policy of cost recovery and revenue strengthening. Furthermore, the Government will embark on a review of existing earmarking programs to determine those that will be gradually phased out. 30. To rationalize the current system of transfers, the Government will introduce safeguards that any investment project financed with transfers outside the original program (through extra-budgetary transfers) complies with the same prerequisites of any other investment project included in the budget. Furthermore, the Government intends to establish new criteria, consistent with the existing revenue sharing program, for the system of transfers that will be incorporated in a new legal framework for decentralization that will be sent to Congress in 1995. This law will also set the guidelines for a program of decentralization of responsibilities and activities within the public sector. 31. Implementation of the budgetary reform will require the introduction of a new system of public debt management and control in both the MFCP and the BCE as well as the need to strengthen the counterpart units within MFCP in general and the SP, in particular. The new debt information system will be installed before January 1995, when the Government expects to have achieved substantial progress in the restructuring the central budget agencies to give then the institutional capacity to operate the new budget process. 32. Another component of the modernization program is to make effective use of the Modernization of the State LAW (LMOS) to effect a reduction in public sector employment and to accelerate the program of public sector restructuring. The law introduced an incentive program of indemnization for those civil servants who decide to leave the public sector before the end of 1996. The Government expects that an additional 5.5 percent of public employees will take advantage of the program. The present value of the indemnization costs for these additional departures is projected to reach approximately US$195 million, which is
 16 Technical Annex expected to be financed through bonds, which will be retired via proceeds from divestment of assets plus a fraction of the salary savings achieved through those employment reductions. 33. Lessons from general Bank experience: Poor institutional capacity is one of the most important hurdles to the implementation of investment projects in developing countries. Unfortunately, Bank experience with institutional development TA projects has proved disappointing for a variety of reasons. The proposed project would be designed to address these constraints: supply-driven TA, lack of commitment on the part of target institutions; insufficient preparation and short implementation times, based on over-optimistic estimates; TA fund-based, as opposed to project-focused implementation approach; Bank-driven, extremely ambitious scope; weak monitoring, lacking measurable outputs; and excessive reliance on expatriate consultants. 35. Successful TA projects, on the other hand, exhibit some characteristics which the proposed project would strive to replicate: avoiding the danger of institutional proliferation by utilizing and strengthening existing institutions rather than creating new ones, and dismantling unnecessary ones; introducing standard or routinized management and administrative procedures; and establishing a process approach to project methodology with well-defined, measurable results to facilitate project management and monitoring. 36. In the LAC region, TA projects follow patterns that confirm the global experience, with the added complexity of multiple components, implementing agencies and donors. Another lesson from past experience, the need for in-depth analytic and sector work to precede public sector reform TA projects, has been met in this case, as a major Public Expenditure Review, which analyzed the fundamental issues facing Ecuador's public sector, including its budgetary and civil service arrangements, preceded project preparation. 37. This estimate illustrates the need to establish a strategy and detailed financing plan for the restructuring process to ensure that adequate financing will exist to liquidate these liabilities. The magnitude of this anticipated liability underscores, in addition, the impossibility of financing these costs without recourse to fiscal instruments, such as bonds or loans, that create multiyear budgetary obligations. This is one of the key objectives of the Restructuring Financing Plan within the CRI proposed in this document. In short, the agreements reached in these Financing Plans will create budgetary obligations, not only for the years in which severance payment liabilities are incurred, but also over the entire time period required to finance those liabilities, which period will be specified in the Financing Plan. Context The administrative restructuring process will be administered by the Secretaria Nacional de Desarrollo Administrativo (SENDA). All activities within this Restructuring Program will be in accord with the policies and guidelines established by the Consejo Nacional de Modernizaci6n del Estado (CONAM), consistent with the strategies and actions for decentralization developed by the Secretaria General de Planificaci6n (SGP), in accord with financing requirements established for the Restructuring Program and established by the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit (MFCP), and consistent with the public financial controls established by the Contraloria General del Estado (CGE). Accordingly, the restructuring process will be an integrated process that is consistent with all core Central Government financial and management policies and practices. B. Implementation Strategy To implement this process, a Committee for Development and Technology will be designated for each restructuring entity. This Committee will be comprised by a top level official, designated by the head of the restructuring entity, the entity's Director of Planning, Director of Human Resources and one other official whose functions are related to the reorganization of the entity. In order to undertake an administrative restructuring, a public entity must prepare and execute an Institutional Restructuring Agreement (Convenio de Reestructuraci6n Institucional (CRI)), subject to the approval of CONAM, SENDA and the Ministry of Finance and Public Credit. The restructuring process will include two basic elements: planning and execution of individual Institutional Restructuring Agreements (Convenio de Reestructuraci6n Institucional -- or CRI) and financing of each public entity's restructuring.

Financing Restructurings and Their Impacts It is estimated that the severance payment liabilities that will be incurred through the voluntary retirement of 20,000 additional public employees during the restructuring process mandated by the Modernization of the State Law will total approximately US$195.5 million in present value terms. This estimate illustrates the need to establish a strategy and detailed financing plan for the restructuring process to ensure that adequate financing will exist to liquidate these liabilities. The magnitude of this anticipated liability underscores, in addition, the impossibility of financing these costs without recourse to fiscal instruments, such as bonds or loans, that create multiyear budgetary obligations. This is one of the key objectives of the Restructuring Financing Plan within the CRI proposed in this document. In short, the agreements reached in these Financing Plans will create budgetary obligations, not only for the years in which severance payment liabilities are incurred, but also over the entire time period required to finance those liabilities, which period will be specified in the Financing Plan. This section explains and presents the results of a model developed to simulate and project the financing of the employment reductions and salary enhancements the Government anticipates achieving through the proposed Public Entity Restructuring Program until August of 1996. That model reflects the following costs and benefits: Costs * Voluntary departure severance payments (indemnizaciones) * Salary enhancements
 13 Benefits * Salary savings Administrative costs of undertaking the Public Entity Restructuring program, including implementation of its co-requisite Sistema Integrado de Gesti6n Financiera (SIGEF), are not included in these projections. Those administrative implementation costs are projected to reach approximately US$25.0 million; a magnitude that does not alter the qualitative conclusions of the projected Net Present Value of the proposed Public Entity Restructuring program. This simulation model, consistent with the strategy proposed in this document, anticipates self- financing on the part of the individual public entities undergoing restructuring of approxirnately 55% of the severance payment liabilities, as well as of salary enhancements that will cover 75% of the persomel expenditure savings expected to be achieved through employment reductions. These simulations project a fiscal dividend to the Treasure from this restructuring process with a net present value of approximately US$81.4 million, less roughly US$25.0 million in costs anticipated to be needed to implement the Modernization of the State Program. Net of those implementation costs, the net present value to the Treasury is US$56.4 million. The improved salary savings, coupled with the improved management capacities to be achieved through: * implementation of the new Ley de Presupuestos, including implementation of both the Sistema Integrado de Gestion Financiera (SIGEF) and its affiliated Sistema de Pagos de Red Bancaria (PRG), and * management improvements to be effected through the restructuring process mandated by the Ley de Modernizaci6n and to be implemented through this Public Entity Restructuring Strategy, promise to significantly enhance the quality of public services and the cost-effectiveness with which those services are provided in Ecuador.

Key Aspects of the Model The model reported herein and summarized in Attachment 1 has the following important features, in addition to the assumptions already enumerated above: 1. The following actions are all assumed to occur during the first four years of the restructuring process

Salary savings from employment reductions are assumed to persist for as many years as departed employees could have been expected to have remained employed within the public sector in the absence of the Restructuring Program. 3. All projected future costs and benefits (e.g., salary savings) are fixed in real terms. 4. The discount rate reflects expected real interest rates in Ecuador (i.e., exclusive of inflation), consistent with the projection of future benefits and costs in constant real terms. 5. While the simulations reported in Attachment 1 reflect expectations regarding the overall Central Government-wide restructuring program, the model can readily be calibrated for specific public entities. Due to an absence of data on expected divestments, it was necessary to make an arbitrary assumption about those magnitudes when calibrating the model reported in Attachment 1. It was assumed that divestments would equal 45% of the annual salary reductions achieved through reductions in force. This is a modest assumption, which means that the estimated net present values reported in this Attachment probably err on the side of understating those net benefits. IV. Conclusions The Public Entity Restructuring Program is designed to provide strong incentives to public entities to: * identify precisely what objectives they should design their organization, its activities and resources to achieve; * identify and discharge those workers whose functions are no longer required to attain the entity's key objectives or whose productivity is inadequate to justify their continued employment; * identify and divest those assets that are either unproductive or which impose budgetary opportunity costs that could be more effectively incurred for other uses, such as the financing of severance payment; * implement the financial management systems mandated by the Ley de Presupuestos; * restructure and reorganize the work flow of their entity so as to most efficiently achieve its specific objectives; * provide timely and reliable information on their entity's performance in achieving its stated objectives.
 17 This strategy is also designed to provide a sustainable fiscal dividend to the Treasury of not less than a fixed percentage of the personnel expenditure savings achieved through employment reductions -- 20% has been suggested in the initial proposal. The fiscal dividend parameter, which will be determined by the Government when it finalizes the restructuring strategy, reflects a tradeoff that must be made between creating strong incentives for individual public entities to undertake productive restructurings and providing the Treasury with a fiscal dividend. More specifically, salary savings from retrenchment provide an opportunity to advance two important goals of the Government: (i) improve the performance of public entities in delivering specific services by allowing them to offer more competitive salaries in order to attract more highly qualified employees; and (ii) reap a fiscal dividend, which can be used to ease the pressure on the national Treasury. The draft proposal recommends that a high percentage of these savings -- around 80% -- be dedicated to salary enhancement and financing of required severance payments, both because this provides a greater incentive for public entities to identify and phase out those workers whose functions are redundant or unnecessary or who are not contributing significantly to producing the products for which that entity is responsible, and because, the greater is the reduction in personnel, the greater will be the total salary savings, and hence, the fiscal dividend available to the Treasury.

doc.abstracts: The Modernization of the State Technical Assistance Project will assist the Government in: 1) improving the framework, procedures and systems for public sector financial management and control; 2) laying the strategic foundation and providing initial support for restructuring the public sector, creating the basis for greater managerial efficiency and operational effectiveness; and 3) providing efficiency, sutainability, and transparency to the Government's public sector reform efforts. The project will finance consultant services, computer equipment and software, training, materials and incremental operating costs for: a) a public financial management and control program which includes: a budget system; a public credit system; Government accounting and treasury; auditing; public contracting; a payroll and personnel system; and supporting information systems; b) a public sector modernization program which includes: activities aimed at futher development and strengthening of the strategic planning function; the design, planning and implementation of public sector restructuring and management strengthening; and related public sector training; and c) coordination of the reform program.
